metadata.title: Quantified analysis on the conversion from contact electrification to contact-electro-catalysis and the performance of contact-electro-catalysts

S0021-9517(25)00218-0 10.1016/j.jcat.2025.116153 Fig. 1 From contact electrification to contact-electro-catalysis. (a) Schematic diagram of contact electrification and contact-electro-catalysis under ultrasonication. (b) CE process in an ultrasonic bath and calculation protocol for theoretical transferred charge. The contact separation cycle denotes the pre-contact, in-contact, and after-contact processes of water with the CEC catalyst, where electrons are transferred from water to the CEC catalyst during the CE process. (c) The activated electrons produced during CE are involved in the subsequent reactive oxygen species generation reaction, i.e., contact-electro-catalysis. The inset at the right end represents the conversion of CE electrons to activated electrons to be involved in catalysis by overcoming the energy potential barrier. Fig. 2 Effect of temperature on activated electrons in contact electrification. (a) Transferred charge between pristine polymer and deionized water recorded by a linear motor-driven single-electrode triboelectric nanogenerator. (b) Calculated transferred charges between FEP and water at 30 °C, 50 °C and 70 °C. (c) Concentration of •OH and •O2 − produced by FEP as the CEC catalyst at 30 °C, 50 °C and 70 °C. (d) CE-to-CEC conversion at 30 ℃, 50 ℃, and 70 ℃. Fig. 3 Effect of ultrasonic frequency on activated electrons in contact electrification. (a) The contact frequency of CEC catalyst with water under different ultrasonic frequencies. (b) Effect of size and number of ultrasound-induced cavitation bubbles on contact frequency and energy. (c) Hydroxyl radical production concentration at different ultrasonic frequencies. (d) Theoretical transferred charges at different ultrasonic frequencies. (e) CE-to-CEC conversion efficiencies that correspond to different ultrasonic frequencies. Fig. 4 Generation of reactive oxygen species by polymers with different CE abilities and normalized activation electrons. (a) Comparison of the concentration of •O2 − produced by polymers with different CE abilities (PE, PP, PVC, PVDF, and FEP). Error bars represent the standard deviation based on three repeated data. (b) Comparison of the concentration of •OH produced by polymers with different CE abilities (PE, PP, PVC, PVDF, and FEP). Error bars represent the standard deviation based on three repeated data. (c) The amount of activation electrons produced by a single contact-separation cycle. Table 1 Parameters corresponding to the theoretical transferred charge between FEP and water over 30 min. Graphical abstract Contact-electro-catalysis (CEC), utilizing electron transfer during contact electrification (CE) to accelerate chemical reactions, has garnered extensive attention as an emerging field. However, how many activated electrons produced during CE participate in the CEC are necessary to be quantitatively analyzed for further improving the CEC reaction. Hence, we introduce an analytical method for investigating CE-to-CEC conversion at various temperatures and ultrasonic conditions, as well as a quantitative metric of the amount of activated electrons in a single charge transfer cycle for evaluating the performance of different CEC catalysts. This study elucidates the proportion of electrons involved in CEC during CE, which provides insights on the transition from CE to CEC, and facilitates further optimization researches for CEC. Keywords Contact electrification Contact-electro-catalysis Activated electron Conversion Quantified analysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Contact electrification (CE) is widespread at a variety of contact interfaces, and electron transfer during CE has been employed for sensing, [1–4] monitoring, [5–7] and energy conversion, [8–10] e.g., triboelectric nanogenerator [11–13]. Recently, CE-driven electron transfer at the liquid–solid interface has been demonstrated to accelerate chemical reactions, termed contact-electro-catalysis (CEC) [14–17]. Serving as a significant complement to existing catalytic strategies, [18–20] CEC, grounded in the CE principle, offers several advantages: a wide spectrum of catalyst selection, mild reaction conditions, and environmental sustainability. Since its introduction, substantial research efforts have concentrated on optimizing CEC performance, [21–23] exploring mechanical stimulation methods, [24,25] and assessing practical reactive applications [26–29]. However, a generalized quantified analysis on the activated electrons produced during the CE process, which initiates CEC, is currently lacking. For a typical ultrasound-induced CEC process, ultrasonic waves induce frequent contact-separation cycles between water molecules and catalysts. The contact-separation cycle is defined as the process wherein water molecules approach a catalyst (typically electronegative) to the extent of electron cloud overlap, followed by electron transfer from the water molecules to the catalyst surface.During this process, the electron transfer involves a substantial number of low-energy electrons, accompanied by energy dissipation attributable to heat [30,31] and humidity [32,33]. At the same time, a fraction of electrons accepted by the catalyst surface form ion adsorption (chemical interaction). A small subset of these electrons is further excited to higher energy states due to cavitation-induced energy, exhibiting enhanced reactivity. These activated electrons generated during the CE process participate in subsequent reactions for reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation, i.e., the activation electrons that initiate the CEC. Therefore, a quantitative method from CE to CEC and a common metric for evaluating the performance of CEC are required, which can not only deepen our understanding of the relationship between CE and CEC, but also provide a theoretical reference for further improving the CEC efficiency. Here, taking ultrasound-induced CEC as an example, we propose an analytical method for quantitatively evaluating CE-to-CEC conversion and the influence of temperature, ultrasonic conditions, and materials on CEC performance. Starting from the transferred charge of one single contact-separation cycle (Qc) and the contact frequency (f) between the material and water, we first present the calculated amount of transferred charge between the CEC catalyst and water under ultrasonication. Alternately, we quantified the activated electrons involved in initiating CEC by detecting the superoxide radicals (•O2 −) and hydroxyl radicals (•OH) produced during the process, using spectrophotometry and fluorescence, respectively. Based on the theoretical transferred charges and activation electrons, the CE-to-CEC conversion efficiencies under different conditions can be determined. Specifically, we investigated the CE-to-CEC conversion efficiencies at varying temperatures (30 °C, 50 °C, and 70 °C) and ultrasonic frequencies (20 kHz, 28 kHz, 40 kHz, and 89 kHz), where Qc and f were modulated by temperature and ultrasonic frequency, respectively. Furthermore, in order to characterize and compare the CEC performance of various materials, we selected polyethylene (PE), polypropylene (PP), polyvinyl chloride (PVC), polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) and polyvinylidene fluoride (FEP) as the CEC catalysts to calculate the number of activation electrons produced in each contact separation cycle, and developed a quantitative metric for evaluating the CEC performance. We expect that the proposed methods will provide theoretical guidance for strategies to further enhance CEC efficiency and lay the foundation for the establishment of the quantitative contact-electro-catalytic diagram. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Chemicals and materials Materials were obtained from commercial suppliers and were not further modified unless otherwise stated. Fluorinated ethylene propylene (FEP), polypropylene (PP), and polyethylene (PE) were acquired from Dupont, polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) from ZHIMK TECHNLOGY (Shenzhen) Co., and polyvinyl chloride (PVC) from Kumho. The nitrotetrazolium blue chloride (C40H30N10O6·2Cl, 98 %) was purchased from Macklin. The aqueous solution was prepared with deionized water having a resistivity of 18.2 MΩ cm. 2.2 Sample preparation and characterization The terephthalic acid solution (THA, p-C6H4(COOH)2) was prepared by adding 332.4 mg of p-phthalic acid and 760 mg of sodium phosphate tribasic dodecahydrate. The nitrotetrazolium blue chlozride solution (NBT) was prepared by adding 10 mg C40H30N10O6·2Cl to 1 L of deionized water. The fluorescence emission spectra of the aliquots were recorded on an Edinburgh Instruments FLS 980 with an excitation wavelength of 312 nm and the characteristic THA-OH peak appearing at 426 nm. The absorbance of the reduction product of NBT was measured by a Cary 3500 UV–Visible Multicell and its characteristic peak appeared at 259 nm. The samples were placed into a Hellma Analytics QS High precision cuvette with the light path of 10 mm. The electrical signal outputs of the triboelectric nanogenerator in single-electrode mode were recorded by an electrostatic meter (Keithley 6514) with a linear motor. The size of the FEP film used to measure surface charge density is around 5 cm × 5 cm. 3 Results and Discussion 3.1 Contact electrification and its stimulated contact-electro-catalysis Fig. 1 a depicts a schematic diagram of CE between a contact-electro-catalyst (usually an electronegative material) and water under ultrasonication and common forms of initialization of CEC. Fig. 1 b shows a schematic of the calculation process of the theoretical transferred charge. The f between FEP and water could be derived from the number of cavitation events and the coverage proportion of FEP on the water surface ( η FEP = 19.85 %, Fig. S1 ). Specifically, in our experiments, at an ultrasonic frequency of 40 kHz, 2 × 108 cavitation events [34] can be generated in a beaker containing 50 ml of solution in 1 s, and the radius of the cavitation bubbles is about 73.6 μm [35]. The void fraction of cavitation bubble [34] is: (1) α ≈ 1.5 × 10 - 4 Considering that the superhydrophobic polymer mainly floats on the solution surface, and only cavitation bubbles that come to the surface region will cause CE between FEP particles and water, we first count the number of cavitation events that occur on the solution surface. Based on the void fraction, the bubble diameter, and the height (2.5 cm) of the liquid level of the beaker, we obtain: (2) C surface = 2 × 10 8 × 73.6 × 2 × 10 - 6 2.5 × 10 - 2 × 1.5 × 10 - 4 1 3 = 2.216 × 10 7 e v e n t s Based on the Monte Carlo model, bubbles on the surface region have a probability of causing a CE between FEP and water, which is assumed to be the FEP coverage proportion mentioned above ( η FEP ). Then, the total number of CE in one second, which is also the CE frequency, can be expressed as: (3) f = η FEP ∙ C surface = 19.85 % × 2.216 × 10 7 = 4.40 × 10 6 H z According to Eqs. (1) and (4), the transferred charge quantity between FEP and water within 1 s can be obtained: (4) Q 1 s = Q C ∙ f = 0.067 C where Q C is 0.01514 μC for the case of FEP (Supplementary Note 1). And the theoretical number of moles of transferred charge between FEP and water over 30 min under ultrasonication was: (5) n e = Q t e ∙ N A = 1.245 × 10 - 3 m o l where Q t refers to the total transferred charge between the FEP and the water in 30 min, e is the elementary charge, and N A is Avogadro constant. The parameters calculated using FEP as the CEC catalyst are shown in Table 1 . Fig. 1 c illustrates that a limited number of electrons triggered CEC during the CE process due to the absorption of higher energy, and these activated electrons were involved in the subsequent ROS production reaction, where •O2 − and •OH were detected by nitrotetrazolium blue chloride (NBT) and terephthalic acid (THA), respectively. The inset on the right side depicts the conversion of a small fraction of CE electrons to activated electrons engaged in CEC by overcoming the energy barrier, referred to as CE-to-CEC conversion. Here, the CE-to-CEC conversion efficiency is defined as the ratio of activated electrons to the theoretical transferred electrons. The calculation of the yield of activated electrons involved in CEC is detailed in Supplementary Note 2, and thus the CE-to-CEC conversion efficiencies can be obtained under various conditions. 3.2 CE-to-CEC conversion at different temperatures The temperature of the liquid medium influences the quantity of transferred charge and catalysis. Based on this, we investigated the CE electrons and activated electrons at 30 °C, 50 °C and 70 °C. We assessed the surface charge density of FEP films at various temperatures by repetitive contact separation of a single-electrode triboelectric nanogenerator [36] with deionized water, as illustrated in Fig. 2 a. The transferred charges between the FEP film and water at temperatures of 30 °C, 50 °C and 70 °C are demonstrated in Fig. S2 , revealing a decreasing trend with increasing temperature. Specifically, FEP demonstrates a maximum charge transfer of 47.53 nC at 30 °C, followed by 50 °C (34.12 nC) and 70 °C (9.06 nC). The theoretical transferred charges at the corresponding temperatures are 12.451 × 10−4, 9.304 × 10−4, and 2.768 × 10−4 mol, respectively (Fig. 2 b). Similarly, both •OH and •O2 − concentrations produced by FEP as the CEC catalyst showed a decreasing trend with increasing temperature, as depicted in Fig. 2 c. The concentration of •OH produced decreased from 14.681 to 11.669 μmol L−1 as the temperature increased from 30 °C to 70 °C. Additionally, the concentration of •O2 − produced correspondingly decreased from 8.551 to 6.144 μmol L−1. The obtained results indicate that both the theoretical transferred electrons and the activated electrons devoted to CEC were suppressed with the increasing temperature. However, the influence of temperature on the theoretical transferred charge is more pronounced. Further, the CE-to-CEC conversion in Fig. 2 d supports this observation, with higher temperatures yielding higher CE-to-CEC conversion efficiencies. The influence mechanism of temperature on interfacial charge transfer may involve competitive effects. Elevated temperatures could significantly increase the thermal kinetic energy of water molecules (proportional to kBT), leading to higher collisional energy, while simultaneously enhancing thermionic emission. Additionally, high temperatures may alter the molecular structure of polymers (glass transition), the viscous transition and thermal softening of the FEP molecular chains reduce the charge exchange at the interface in contact with water. We measured the surface potential distribution of the FEP film at elevated temperatures using an electrostatic voltmeter (Trek 520), as shown in Fig. S3 , where the average surface potential decreased from−0.312 kV at 30 °C to−0.179 kV at 70 °C, demonstrating that a portion of the electrons are thermally emitted [31] at elevated temperatures rather than being transferred. To further distinguish the effects of polymer structure and temperature on interfacial charge transfer, we measured the triboelectric properties of FEP films under three conditions (Fig. S4, pristine FEP film at room temperature, FEP film heated and cooled back to room temperature, and FEP film at elevated temperature). The results reveal that structural reorganization dominates the decline in triboelectric performance at high temperatures (accounting for 60.1 % of the total effect). Furthermore, thermal treatment induces irreversible structural changes in FEP, which permanently degrade its charge transfer performance. Consequently, temperature exhibits a nonlinear effect on the CE-to-CEC conversion efficiency. These experimental results further illustrate the nonlinear effect of temperature on the charge transfer in the CE process and that the synthesis of catalysts with superior CE capability at high temperatures is a feasible strategy for achieving high CEC efficiency. 3.3 Impact of the ultrasonic frequency The impact of ultrasonic frequency on CE-to-CEC conversion was examined, as it significantly influences the contact frequency between the CEC catalyst and water. Exemplified by the FEP as the CEC catalyst, Fig. 3 a depicts the contact frequencies of FEP with water at 20 kHz, 28 kHz, 40 kHz, and 89 kHz. The contact frequencies of FEP with water at the corresponding ultrasonic frequencies are 1.35 × 106 Hz, 2.25 × 106 Hz, 4.40 × 106 Hz, and 1.49 × 107 Hz, respectively (Table 2 ), from which we can find that as the ultrasonic frequency increases, the cavitation number increases, but the bubble size decreases, which then significantly influences the CEC performance. The FEP-catalyzed NBT reduction and fluorescent THA-OH production at different ultrasonic frequencies are shown in Figs. S5 and S6 , respectively, and the both show the same evolution trend, i.e., the highest concentrations of •O2 − and •OH were produced at 40 kHz. The difference in the catalytic activity of FEP due to ultrasonic frequency is schematically illustrated in Fig. 3 b. Higher ultrasonic frequencies result in lower energy input to the ultrasonic bath due to the lower energy released by the collapse of smaller cavitation bubbles [35,37], and hence the decrease in the number of activated electrons at the catalytic interface, which could account for the lowest catalytic activity of FEP at 89 kHz. Alternatively, lower ultrasonic frequencies tend to introduce cavitation bubbles with larger sizes, and the cracking of these cavitation bubbles provides a greater energy input [38], however, the contact frequency of the FEP with water is consequently reduced. The potential energy contained in a cavitation bubble is proportional to the cube of its size [38], with the following expression, and decreases with increasing ultrasonic frequency (Table 2). (6) E B = 4 3 π p ∞ - p v R max 3 Where R max is the maximum radius of the bubble, p v is the saturated vapor pressure of water, and p ∞ is the ambient pressure. Therefore, optimum values of catalytic activity of FEP should exist within a certain range of ultrasonic frequencies. Fig. 3 c demonstrates the FEP-catalyzed •OH concentration at different ultrasonic frequencies, producing a highest concentration of 14.681 μmol L−1 at 40 kHz, with a trend in line with our expectations. Since CE electrons are mainly related to the contact frequency and the CE capability of the catalyst, the highest number of transferred electrons were generated between FEP and water at 89 kHz (42.098 × 10−4 mol), followed by 40 kHz (12.451 × 10−4 mol), 28 kHz (6.364 × 10−4 mol) and 20 kHz (3.806 × 10−4 mol). This result suggests that the CEC efficiency is only dictated by the number of activated electrons. The relationship between CE electrons and activation electrons at different ultrasonic frequencies is further illustrated by the CE-to-CEC efficiencies in Fig. 3 e, where the CE-to-CEC efficiencies decrease from 0.2515 % to 0.0193 % with ultrasonic frequency. These results not only deepen the understanding of the differences in the activity of the CEC catalysts due to different ultrasonic frequencies, but also provide guidance in selecting the appropriate stimulation conditions for CEC. 3.4 Normalized activation electrons for evaluation of CEC catalyst performance CE-to-CEC conversion describes the external conditions such as medium temperature, ultrasonic conditions, etc. that affect CEC efficiency, and a quantitative evaluation metric is required for CEC catalysts. Exemplified by the pristine polymers commonly employed for current CEC catalysts, we selected polymers with different CE abilities (FEP, PVDF, PVC, PP, and PE), investigated their catalytic performances, and established a normalized metric for evaluating CEC performance. Fig. S7 demonstrates the NBT reduction catalyzed by the above polymers, and the reduction ratio is closely related to the CE ability of the polymers, with FEP exhibiting the highest NBT reduction ratio due to more F groups, followed by PVDF, PVC, PP, and PE. Based on this, the concentrations of •O2 − produced by the corresponding catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 a. The experimental results indicated that FEP exhibits the highest catalytic ability in generating •O2 −. Furthermore, the intensity of fluorescent THA-OH adducts in the presence of different polymer catalysts is presented in Fig. S8 . The concentration of •OH produced by the corresponding catalysts is shown in Fig. 4 b, which increases from 0.1004 μmol L−1 (catalyzed by PE) to 14.681 μmol L−1 (catalyzed by FEP), and this increasing trend is the same as that of •O2 −.This difference in catalytic performance can be explained by the fact that polymers with the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals of lower energy level (e.g., FEP) usually hold a stronger CE ability, [39] exchanging more electrons during CE with water, and thus having the chance to generate more activated electrons for catalyzing the ROS generation. The transferred charges of the polymers after CE with water were exhibited in Fig. S9 . To further compare the activities of different CEC catalysts, we established a unified metric for evaluating the performance of CEC, i.e., the amount of activation electrons generated by a single contact-separation cycle. Taking FEP as an example, the number of contact-separation cycles with water in 30 min can be obtained as: (7) C = 4.40 × 10 6 × 60 × 30 = 7.92 × 10 9 c y c l e s Thus, the number of moles of activated electrons in a single cycle is: (8) n s = n activationelectrons C Then, the amount of activation electrons produced by a single contact-separation cycle can be obtained from Eq. (8), as shown in Fig. 4 c. Further, we calculated η ( Fig. S10 ) and the corresponding f for different polymers on the aqueous surface in order to establish a unified metric for evaluating the intrinsic activity of the catalysts (Table 3 ). Compared to PE, which exhibits negligible triboelectric performance with water, FEP with perfluoro groups demonstrates approximately a 122-fold enhancement in catalytic activity, thereby confirming the dominant role of CE over CEC. These calculations not only further evaluate the activity of different CEC catalysts, but also help to establish a quantitative contact-electro-catalytic diagram. 4 Conclusions We have investigated the effects of external factors such as medium temperature and ultrasound parameters on CE electrons and activated electrons during the CE process, as well as established a quantitative metric for evaluating the performance of CEC catalysts. Starting with the calculation of theoretical CE electrons and activated electrons, a CE-to-CEC conversion efficiency of 0.0934 % was obtained under typical CEC conditions (40 kHz, 30 ℃). By adjusting various temperature and ultrasonic parameters, the changes in CE-to-CEC conversion efficiency guide the selection of more efficient CEC triggering protocols and provide valuable insights for improving CEC efficiency under specific conditions. Furthermore, we introduced a uniform metric for evaluating the activity of different CEC catalysts by utilizing polymers with different CE abilities as catalysts. We expect that this work not only deepens the understanding of the relationship between CE and CEC, but also lays the foundation for establishing an quantitative contact-electro-catalytic diagram. coredata.dc:description: Contact-electro-catalysis (CEC), utilizing electron transfer during contact electrification (CE) to accelerate chemical reactions, has garnered extensive attention as an emerging field. However, how many activated electrons produced during CE participate in the CEC are necessary to be quantitatively analyzed for further improving the CEC reaction. Hence, we introduce an analytical method for investigating CE-to-CEC conversion at various temperatures and ultrasonic conditions, as well as a quantitative metric of the amount of activated electrons in a single charge transfer cycle for evaluating the performance of different CEC catalysts. This study elucidates the proportion of electrons involved in CEC during CE, which provides insights on the transition from CE to CEC, and facilitates further optimization researches for CEC.
coredata.dc:title: Quantified analysis on the conversion from contact electrification to contact-electro-catalysis and the performance of contact-electro-catalysts
